findings.title: C01. Token Supply Manipulation
findings.description: An attacker can manipulate token supply by depositing small amounts from multiple addresses and waiting to accumulate time delta, then using a FlashLoan to make a large second deposit and withdraw the deposit and rewards without actively staking funds.

findings.title: H05. Data Inconsistency
findings.description: The crucial invariant that the balance of the company should be equal to the sum of user balances can be broken if the company address calls the `mint()` function.

findings.title: M01. Dangerous Strict Zero Equality
findings.description: The value `rewardAmount` is derived based on complex calculations which can lead to non-strict zero values due to binary number representation inside the EVM.

findings.title: M04. Undocumented Functionality
findings.description: The owner of the MasterChef contract can change pool.rewardLockupBlock on demand, leading to an infinite lock in the stacking contract.

findings.title: M05. Missing Functionality
findings.description: N/A

findings.title: M06. Using Block Number Attribute as a Proxy of Time
findings.description: The contract takes a constructor parameter `blocksPerYear` and calculates rewards based on this value. Blocks per year is not a constant value and can lead to a serious fault if used as a time reference.

findings.title: M07. Best Practice Violation - Unchecked Transfer
findings.description: Not using OpenZeppelin’s SafeERC20 library and instead calling transfer() directly which can lead to unchecked transfers.

findings.title: L01. Redundant Modifiers
findings.description: The `virtual` modifier is superfluous in the functions of the top level contracts.

findings.title: L02. Floating Pragma
findings.description: Contracts should be deployed with the same compiler version and flags that they have been tested thoroughly.

findings.title: L03. Style Guide Violation - Implicit State Visibility
findings.description: Implicit state visibility is a style guide violation.

findings.title: L04. Style Guide Violation - Visibility Modifiers
findings.description: Best practice to put visibility modifiers first in the list of function modifiers.

findings.title: L05. Style Guide Violation - Incorrect Function Order
findings.description: Public functions should not be declared after public view functions.

findings.title: L06. Style Guide Violation - Unused Function Parameters
findings.description: The code contains an overridden function with unused, yet named parameters.

findings.title: L07. Unfinished NatSpec
findings.description: N/A

findings.title: L08. Missing Zero Address Validation
findings.description: Address parameters are used without checking against the possibility of 0x0, which can lead to unwanted external calls to 0x0.

findings.title: L09. Unindexed Events
findings.description: Having indexed parameters in the events makes it easier to search for these events using indexed parameters as filters.

findings.title: L10. Unnecessary Code Complication
findings.description: N/A

findings.title: L11. Missing Zero Check - Uint
findings.description: The functions can receive a zero `_amount` parameter which will still cause unintended behavior.

findings.title: L12. Functions That Can Be Declared External
findings.description: Public functions that are never called in the contract should be declared as external to save Gas.

findings.title: L13. Redundant Code
findings.description: N/A

findings.title: L14. Redundant Use of SafeMath
findings.description: The use of SafeMath library is redundant as it can be replaced by ABIEncoderV2 on the language level which adds validation to bytecode during compilation.

findings.title: L15. Redundant Imports
findings.description: The use of unnecessary imports will increase the Gas consumption of the code and decrease code readability.

findings.title: L16. Style Guide Violation
findings.description: Style guide violation
